title: Jury Finds Rally Organizers Responsible for Charlottesville Violence
content: Jurors found the main organizers of the deadly right-wing rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law, awarding more than $25 million in damages, but deadlocked on federal conspiracy charges.

title: CVS, Walgreens and Walmart Perpetuated Opioid Crisis, Jury Finds
content: This is the first jury verdict in an opioids case. The decision embraced a key legal argument that judges in other opioids cases had recently rejected.

title: Contending with the Pandemic, Wealthy Nations Wage Global Battle for Migrants
content: Covid kept many people in place. Now several developed countries, facing aging labor forces and worker shortages, are racing to recruit, train and integrate foreigners.

more_info.byline: By Damien Cave and Christopher F. Schuetze

title: As Virus Cases Rise in Europe, an Economic Toll Returns
content: A series of restrictions, including a lockdown in Austria, is expected to put a brake on economic growth.

more_info.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy

title: Epstein’s Final Days: Celebrity Reminiscing and a Running Toilet
content: Newly released records show the disgraced financier living a mundane existence in jail before his suicide, while also spinning deceptions until the very end.

more_info.byline: By Benjamin Weiser, Matthew Goldstein, Danielle Ivory and Steve Eder

title: House Panel Investigating Capitol Attack Subpoenas Proud Boys and Oath Keepers
content: Investigators believe the militia or paramilitary groups have information about the deadly siege on Jan. 6.

title: Hayao Miyazaki Prepares to Cast One Last Spell
content: No artist has explored the contradictions of humanity as sympathetically and critically as the Japanese animation legend. Now, at 80, he’s coming out of retirement with another movie.

title: 8 Spectacular Pies That Taste as Good as They Look
content: Vibrant fillings, bold finishes — here are brilliant new pies to make for Thanksgiving.

title: A Thanksgiving History Lesson, in a Handful of Corn
content: The cornmeal that has become a staple of the holiday table reflects millenniums of work by Native Americans — a legacy that Indigenous people are trying to keep alive.

title: How to Make Your Thanksgiving Dinner Less Boring
content: Samin Nosrat will say it: Every year, the meal is a lot of the same. Here are five ways she adds brightness, crunch, freshness and flavor.

title: Jon Batiste and Young Chart-Toppers Lead 2022 Grammy Nominations
content: The Recording Academy, which expanded the top competitions to 10 slots, announces its first ballot since ending its heavily criticized review committees in nearly all categories.

title: Grammys Snubs and Surprises: Kacey Musgraves, Jon Batiste and Abba

content: Artists, albums and songs competing for trophies at the 64th annual ceremony were announced on Tuesday. The show will take place Jan. 31 in Los Angeles.

title: We’re a Small Arkansas Newspaper. Why Is the State Making Us Sign a Pledge About Israel?
content: I publish The Arkansas Times. We refused to sign an anti-B.D.S. law because it violates our First Amendment rights.

title: Kenosha, Portland, and the Lies We Must Leave Behind
content: What I saw in Portland and Kenosha has convinced me: We must stop tearing ourselves apart so that we can build.

content: Being denied an abortion can have serious consequences for a woman’s health and livelihood. It can even be deadly.

title: Powell Needs to Cool the Economy Now to Avoid Recession Later
content: Now that Jerome Powell has been renominated to head the Federal Reserve, he needs to turn the temperature down.

content: On Thanksgiving, consider the multiple benefits of giving thanks.

title: As Thanksgiving Approaches, U.S. Virus Cases Tick Upward Once More
content: Cases are rising again in parts of the country, but more people are traveling, and health officials have largely stopped telling people to skip celebrations.

title: A Socialite, a Gardener, a Message in Blood: The Murder That Still Grips France
content: The victim was a socialite. A message in her blood accused the gardener. But a grammatical error raised questions of class and language — and whether he was being framed.

content: Will work ever love us back? Two millennials disagree.

title: Biden’s Low-Key Media Strategy Draws Allies’ Concern
content: So far in his tenure, the president has given far fewer one-on-one interviews than his two predecessors. Some Democrats are asking if he could be making better use of his White House pulpit.

title: Maj. Ian Fishback, Who Exposed Abuse of Detainees, Dies at 42
content: His letter to two senators about beatings by U.S. troops in Iraq led to legislation in 2005 prohibiting extreme mistreatment of military prisoners.

title: Apple Sues Israeli Spyware Maker, Seeking to Block Its Access to iPhones
content: Apple accused NSO Group, the Israeli surveillance company, of “flagrant” violations of its software, as well as federal and state laws.

title: Malikah Shabazz, Daughter of Malcolm X, Is Found Dead in Brooklyn
content: Ms. Shabazz was found in her living room by her daughter on Monday. The police do not suspect foul play.

title: Italy Frees Convicted Killer of U.K. Student Meredith Kercher
content: Rudy Guede had served 13 years of a 16-year sentence for the 2007 murder. Another student, Amanda Knox, was eventually exonerated in what became a polarizing case.

content: Mr. Strahan, a “Good Morning America” co-host, is one of six people set to join the next spaceflight with Blue Origin, the rocket company founded by Jeff Bezos.

title: Kevin Spacey was ordered to pay $31 million to the ‘House of Cards’ studio after sexual harassment allegations.
content: A secret arbitrator’s ruling was issued 13 months ago and became public on Monday when lawyers for the studio petitioned a California court to confirm the award.

title: After 20 Years, Frank Stella Returns to Ground Zero
content: The installation of his sculpture marks a homecoming for the 85-year-old artist, whose diptych at the World Trade Center was destroyed on 9/11.

title: It’s Never Too Late to Pick Up Your Life and Move to Italy
content: Holly Herrmann vowed to move to Italy when she was 20. Her dream came true 38 years later.

title: Are the Knicks and Lakers Really Worth $5 Billion?
content: Sports franchise valuations are guesses, with few data points for comparison. But prestige franchises like these can defy all calculations.
